declarations.comments: Extracts an `Iso` from `AnIso`.

declarations.comments:
Converts a lens into the form that `lens'` accepts.

Can be useful when defining a lens where the focus appears under multiple
constructors of an algebraic data type.  This function would be called for
each case of the data type.

For example:

```
data LensStoreExample = LensStoreA Int | LensStoreB (Tuple Boolean Int)

lensStoreExampleInt :: Lens' LensStoreExample Int
lensStoreExampleInt = lens' case _ of
  LensStoreA i -> map LensStoreA <$> lensStore identity i
  LensStoreB i -> map LensStoreB <$> lensStore _2 i
```
declarations.title: lensStore

declarations.comments:
Create a `Lens` from a getter/setter pair.

```purescript
> species = lens _.species $ _ {species = _}
> view species {species : "bovine"}
"bovine"

> _2 = lens Tuple.snd $ \(Tuple keep _) new -> Tuple keep new
```

Note: `_2` is predefined in `Data.Lens.Tuple`.
declarations.title: lens

declarations.comments:
Create the "whole" corresponding to a specific "part":

```purescript
review solidFocus Color.white == Solid Color.white
```
declarations.title: review

declarations.comments:
Create a `Prism` from a constructor and a matcher function that
produces a `Maybe`:

```purescript
solidFocus :: Prism' Fill Color
solidFocus = prism' Solid case _ of
  Solid color -> Just color
  _ -> Nothing
```
declarations.title: prism'

declarations.comments:
Create a `Prism` from a constructor and a matcher function that
produces an `Either`:

```purescript
solidFocus :: Prism' Fill Color
solidFocus = prism Solid case _ of
  Solid color -> Right color
  anotherCase -> Left anotherCase
```

_Note_: The matcher function returns a result wrapped in `Either t`
to allow for type-changing prisms in the case where the input does
not match.
declarations.title: prism

declarations.comments:
`only` focuses not just on a case, but a specific value of that case.

```purescript
solidWhiteFocus :: Prism' Fill Unit
solidWhiteFocus = only $ Solid Color.white

is      solidWhiteFocus (Solid Color.white) == true
preview solidWhiteFocus (Solid Color.white) == Just unit
review  solidWhiteFocus unit                == Solid Color.white
```

*Note*: `only` depends on `Eq`. Strange definitions of `(==)`
(for example, that it counts any `Fill` as being equal to `Solid Color.white`)
will create a prism that violates the preview-review law.
declarations.title: only

declarations.comments:
`nearly` is a variant of `only`. Like `only`, `nearly` produces
a prism that matches
a single value. Unlike `only`, it uses a predicate you supply
instead of depending on `class Eq`: 

```purescript
solidWhiteFocus :: Prism' Fill Unit
solidWhiteFocus = nearly (Solid Color.white) predicate
  where
    predicate candidate =
      color.toHexString == Color.white.toHexString
```
declarations.title: nearly

declarations.comments: Ask if `preview prism` would produce a `Nothing`.
declarations.title: isn't

declarations.comments: Ask if `preview prism` would produce a `Just`.
declarations.title: is

declarations.comments: Set the foci of a `Setter` to a constant value.
declarations.title: set

declarations.comments: Apply a function to the foci of a `Setter`.
declarations.title: over

declarations.comments: Modify the foci of a `Setter` in a monadic state.
declarations.title: modifying

declarations.comments: Apply a function to the foci of a `Setter` that may vary with the index.
declarations.title: iover

declarations.comments: Set the foci of a `Setter` in a monadic state to a constant value.
declarations.title: assign

declarations.comments:
A `Traversal` for the elements of a `Traversable` functor.

```purescript
over traversed negate [1, 2, 3] == [-1,-2,-3]
over traversed negate (Just 3) == Just -3
```
declarations.title: traversed

declarations.comments: Turn a pure profunctor `Traversal` into a `lens`-like `Traversal`.
declarations.title: traverseOf

declarations.comments:
Sequence the foci of an optic, pulling out an "effect".
If you do not need the result, see `sequenceOf_` for `Fold`s.

`sequenceOf traversed` has the same result as `Data.Traversable.sequence`:

```purescript
sequenceOf traversed (Just [1, 2]) == [Just 1, Just 2]
sequence             (Just [1, 2]) == [Just 1, Just 2]
```

An example with effects:
```purescript
> array = [random, random]
> :t array
Array (Eff ... Number)

> effect = sequenceOf traversed array
> :t effect
Eff ... (Array Number)

> effect >>= logShow
[0.15556037108154985,0.28500369615270515]
unit
```
declarations.title: sequenceOf

declarations.comments: Turn a pure profunctor `IndexedTraversal` into a `lens`-like `IndexedTraversal`.
declarations.title: itraverseOf

declarations.comments:
Tries to map over a `Traversal`; returns `empty` if the traversal did
not have any new focus.
declarations.title: failover

declarations.comments: Traverse elements of an `IndexedTraversal` whose index satisfy a predicate.
declarations.title: elementsOf

declarations.comments:
Combine an index and a traversal to narrow the focus to a single
element. Compare to `Data.Lens.Index`. 

```purescript
set     (element 2 traversed) 8888 [0, 0, 3] == [0, 0, 8888]
preview (element 2 traversed)      [0, 0, 3] == Just 3
```
The resulting traversal is called an *affine traversal*, which
means that the traversal focuses on one or zero (if the index is out of range)
results.
declarations.title: element

declarations.comments: A traversal.
declarations.title: Traversal

declarations.comments: The `Shop` profunctor characterizes a `Lens`.
declarations.title: Shop

declarations.comments: A setter.
declarations.title: Setter

declarations.comments: A prism.
declarations.title: Prism

declarations.comments: The `Market` profunctor characterizes a `Prism`.
declarations.title: Market

declarations.comments:
`Lens'` is a specialization of `Lens`. An optic of type `Lens'`
can change only the value of its focus,
not its type. As an example, consider the `Lens` `_2`, which has this type:

```purescript
_2 :: forall s t a b. Lens (Tuple s a) (Tuple t b) a b
```

`_2` can produce a `Tuple Int String` from a `Tuple Int Int`:

```purescript
set _2 "NEW" (Tuple 1 2) == (Tuple 1 "NEW")
```

If we specialize `_2`'s type with `Lens'`, the following will not
type check:

```purescript
set (_2 :: Lens' (Tuple Int Int) Int) "NEW" (Tuple 1 2)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens'

declarations.comments:
Given a type whose "focus element" always exists,
a lens provides a convenient way to view, set, and transform
that element.

For example, `_2` is a tuple-specific `Lens` available from `Data.Lens`, so:
```purescript
over _2 String.length $ Tuple "ignore" "four" == Tuple "ignore" 4
```
Note the result has a different type than the original tuple.
That is, the four `Lens` type variables have been narrowed to:

* `s` is `Tuple String String`
* `t` is `Tuple String Int`
* `a` is `String`
* `b` is `Int`

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens

declarations.comments: A generalized isomorphism.
declarations.title: Iso

declarations.comments: An indexed traversal.
declarations.title: IndexedTraversal

declarations.comments: An indexed setter.
declarations.title: IndexedSetter

declarations.comments: The `Exchange` profunctor characterizes an `Iso`.
declarations.title: Exchange

declarations.comments: Class for profunctors that support polymorphic traversals.
declarations.title: Wander

modules.name: Data.Lens.AffineTraversal
modules.comments:
This module defines functions for working with affine traversals.
An `AffineTraversal` is a `Traversal` that applies to at most one element.

These arise most frequently as the composition of a `Lens` with a `Prism`.

declarations.comments:
`At` is a type class whose instances let you add
new elements or delete old ones from "container-like" types:

```purescript
whole = Map.singleton "key" "value"
optic = at "key"

view optic whole == Just "value"

set optic (Just "NEW") whole == Map.singleton "key" "NEW"

set optic Nothing whole == Map.empty
```

If you don't want to add or delete, but only to view or change
an existing element, see `Data.Lens.Index`.
declarations.title: At

declarations.comments: Lens for the second component of a `Tuple`.
Lens for the first component of a `Tuple`.
There is a `Unit` in everything.
declarations.title: united

declarations.comments: Prism for the `Right` constructor of `Either`.
declarations.title: _Right

declarations.title: _Just

modules.name: Data.Lens.Common
modules.comments: This module defines common lenses and prisms.

declarations.comments:
This is useful for when you want to restrict the type of another optic.
For example, suppose you have the following declarations:
```purescript
newtype X = X Int
derive instance newtypeX :: Newtype X _
```

Attempting to view with the `_Newtype` optic:
```purescript
X 42 ^. _Newtype
```
Will result in a type error:
```
 The inferred type
   forall t3 t5. Newtype t3 t5 => Int
 has type variables which are not mentioned in the body of the type.
 Consider adding a type annotation.
```

However, if we apply the `simple` function:
```purescript
 X 42 ^. simple _Newtype
```
We get the expected result `42`.
declarations.title: simple

modules.name: Data.Lens.Grate
modules.comments:
This module defines functions for working with grates.

See <http://r6research.livejournal.com/28050.html>.

declarations.comments:
`Index` is a type class whose instances are optics used when:
1. The focus element might not be present.
2. You either cannot or do not want to add new elements or delete existing ones.

`Array` is a typical example:

```purescript
preview (ix 1) [0, 1, 2] == Just 1

set (ix 1) 8888 [0, 1, 2] == [0,8888,2]
```

Note the use of `preview` rather `view`. That's because the optic is
a `Data.Lens.Traversal` tailored to the case where there's a single element
of interest.

Another common use is a `Map` that you don't want to either grow or shrink:

```purescript
(set (ix "k") "new" $ Map.singleton "k" "old") == Map.singleton "k" "new"

(set (ix "k") "new" $ Map.empty) == Map.empty
```

Note the second line: an attempt to `set` a missing focus element
leaves the original whole unchanged.

If you *do* want to add or delete elements, see `Data.Lens.At`.
declarations.title: Index

declarations.comments: Converts an `IndexedOptic` to an `Optic` by forgetting indices.
declarations.title: unIndex

declarations.comments: Remap the index.
declarations.title: reindexed

declarations.comments: Converts a `lens`-like indexed traversal to an `IndexedTraversal`.
declarations.title: iwander

declarations.comments: Traverses over a `TraversableWithIndex` container.
declarations.title: itraversed

declarations.comments:
Converts a `Traversal` to an `IndexedTraversal` by using the integer
positions as indices.
declarations.title: positions

declarations.comments:
An Iso between a newtype and its inner type.
Supports switching between different types that have instances of the
Newtype type class.
If you don't need to change types, you may have a better experience with
type inference if you use `simple _Newtype`.
declarations.title: _Newtype

declarations.comments:
A variant of `_Newtype` which takes the constructor as an argument
and infers its inverse.

This is useful as an aid to type inference in certain situations.
declarations.title: unto

declarations.comments:
`Lens'` is a specialization of `Lens`. An optic of type `Lens'`
can change only the value of its focus,
not its type. As an example, consider the `Lens` `_2`, which has this type:

```purescript
_2 :: forall s t a b. Lens (Tuple s a) (Tuple t b) a b
```

`_2` can produce a `Tuple Int String` from a `Tuple Int Int`:

```purescript
set _2 "NEW" (Tuple 1 2) == (Tuple 1 "NEW")
```

If we specialize `_2`'s type with `Lens'`, the following will not
type check:

```purescript
set (_2 :: Lens' (Tuple Int Int) Int) "NEW" (Tuple 1 2)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens'

declarations.comments:
Given a type whose "focus element" always exists,
a lens provides a convenient way to view, set, and transform
that element.

For example, `_2` is a tuple-specific `Lens` available from `Data.Lens`, so:
```purescript
over _2 String.length $ Tuple "ignore" "four" == Tuple "ignore" 4
```
Note the result has a different type than the original tuple.
That is, the four `Lens` type variables have been narrowed to:

* `s` is `Tuple String String`
* `t` is `Tuple String Int`
* `a` is `String`
* `b` is `Int`

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens

declarations.comments: An indexed lens.
declarations.title: IndexedLens

modules.name: Data.Lens.Lens
modules.comments: This module defines functions for working with lenses.

declarations.comments:
Create a `Lens` from a getter/setter pair.

```purescript
> species = lens _.species $ _ {species = _}
> view species {species : "bovine"}
"bovine"

> _2 = lens Tuple.snd $ \(Tuple keep _) new -> Tuple keep new
```

Note: `_2` is predefined in `Data.Lens.Tuple`.
declarations.title: lens

declarations.comments:
Converts a lens into the form that `lens'` accepts.

Can be useful when defining a lens where the focus appears under multiple
constructors of an algebraic data type.  This function would be called for
each case of the data type.

For example:

```
data LensStoreExample = LensStoreA Int | LensStoreB (Tuple Boolean Int)

lensStoreExampleInt :: Lens' LensStoreExample Int
lensStoreExampleInt = lens' case _ of
  LensStoreA i -> map LensStoreA <$> lensStore identity i
  LensStoreB i -> map LensStoreB <$> lensStore _2 i
```
declarations.title: lensStore

declarations.comments: Lens for the first component of a `Product`.
Lens for the second component of a `Product`.
Lens for the first component of a `Tuple`.
Lens for the second component of a `Tuple`.
There is a `Unit` in everything.
declarations.title: united

declarations.comments: There is everything in `Void`.
declarations.title: devoid

declarations.comments: A prism.
declarations.title: Prism

modules.name: Data.Lens.Prism
modules.comments:
Prisms are used for selecting cases of a type, most often a sum
type. Consider this:

```purescript
data Fill -- think of a paint program filling a shape
  = NoFill
  | Solid Color
  | ...
```

A prism that focuses on `Solid` fills could be written like this:

```purescript
solidFocus :: Prism' Fill Color
solidFocus = prism' Solid case _ of
  Solid color -> Just color
  _ -> Nothing
```

... and used like this:

```purescript
preview solidFocus (Solid Color.white) == Just Color.white
preview solidFocus NoFill == Nothing

is solidFocus (Solid Color.white) == true
```

`review` can be used to go from a `Color` to a `Fill`:

```purescript
review solidFocus Color.white == Solid Color.white
```

For more information, see `PrismsForSumTypes.purs` in the
`examples/src` directory.

---------------

A well-behaved `Prism` will follow these laws:

**review-preview**: `preview` retrieves what `review` creates. Equationally:
  
```purescript
review prism >>> preview prism  Just
```

An example:

```purescript
Color.white # review solidFocus # preview solidFocus
  == Just Color.white
```

**preview-review**: If `preview` retrieves something, `review` can create
the original from that something. Equationally:

```purescript
if preview prism s  Just a then review prism a  s
```

An example:

```purescript
Solid Color.white # preview solidFocus <#> review solidFocus
  == Solid Color.white
```

declarations.comments:
Create a `Prism` from a constructor and a matcher function that
produces a `Maybe`:

```purescript
solidFocus :: Prism' Fill Color
solidFocus = prism' Solid case _ of
  Solid color -> Just color
  _ -> Nothing
```
declarations.title: prism'

declarations.comments:
Create a `Prism` from a constructor and a matcher function that
produces an `Either`:

```purescript
solidFocus :: Prism' Fill Color
solidFocus = prism Solid case _ of
  Solid color -> Right color
  anotherCase -> Left anotherCase
```

_Note_: The matcher function returns a result wrapped in `Either t`
to allow for type-changing prisms in the case where the input does
not match.
declarations.title: prism

declarations.comments:
`only` focuses not just on a case, but a specific value of that case.

```purescript
solidWhiteFocus :: Prism' Fill Unit
solidWhiteFocus = only $ Solid Color.white

is      solidWhiteFocus (Solid Color.white) == true
preview solidWhiteFocus (Solid Color.white) == Just unit
review  solidWhiteFocus unit                == Solid Color.white
```

*Note*: `only` depends on `Eq`. Strange definitions of `(==)`
(for example, that it counts any `Fill` as being equal to `Solid Color.white`)
will create a prism that violates the preview-review law.
declarations.title: only

declarations.comments:
`nearly` is a variant of `only`. Like `only`, `nearly` produces
a prism that matches
a single value. Unlike `only`, it uses a predicate you supply
instead of depending on `class Eq`: 

```purescript
solidWhiteFocus :: Prism' Fill Unit
solidWhiteFocus = nearly (Solid Color.white) predicate
  where
    predicate candidate =
      color.toHexString == Color.white.toHexString
```
declarations.title: nearly

declarations.comments:
Create the "whole" corresponding to a specific "part":

```purescript
review solidFocus Color.white == Solid Color.white
```
declarations.title: review

declarations.comments: Ask if `preview prism` would produce a `Just`.
declarations.title: is

declarations.comments: Ask if `preview prism` would produce a `Nothing`.
declarations.title: isn't

declarations.comments: Prism for the `left` of a `Coproduct`.
declarations.title: _Left

declarations.comments: Prism for the `right` of a `Coproduct`.
declarations.title: _Right

declarations.comments: Prism for the `Left` constructor of `Either`.
declarations.title: _Left

declarations.comments: Prism for the `Right` constructor of `Either`.
declarations.title: _Right

declarations.comments: Prism for the `Nothing` constructor of `Maybe`.
declarations.title: _Nothing

declarations.comments: Prism for the `Just` constructor of `Maybe`.
declarations.title: _Just

declarations.comments:
Construct a (type-changing) lens for a record property, by providing a
proxy for the `Symbol` which corresponds to the property label.

The lens is polymorphic in the rest of the row of property labels.

For example:

```purescript
prop (Proxy :: Proxy "foo")
  :: forall a b r. Lens { foo :: a | r } { foo :: b | r } a b
```
declarations.title: prop

declarations.comments: A setter.
declarations.title: Setter

declarations.comments: An indexed setter.
declarations.title: IndexedSetter

modules.name: Data.Lens.Setter
modules.comments: This module defines functions for working with setters.

declarations.comments: Apply a function to the foci of a `Setter`.
declarations.title: over

declarations.comments: Apply a function to the foci of a `Setter` that may vary with the index.
declarations.title: iover

declarations.comments: Set the foci of a `Setter` to a constant value.
declarations.title: set

declarations.comments: Set the foci of a `Setter` in a monadic state to a constant value.
declarations.title: assign

declarations.comments: Modify the foci of a `Setter` in a monadic state.
declarations.title: modifying

declarations.comments: A traversal.
declarations.title: Traversal

modules.name: Data.Lens.Traversal
modules.comments:
`Traversal` is an optic that focuses on zero or more values. An
`Array` would be a typical example:

```purescript
over    traversed negate [1, 2, 3] == [-1, -2, -3]
preview traversed [1, 2, 3] == Just 1
firstOf traversed [1, 2, 3] == Just 1  -- same as `preview`
lastOf  traversed [1, 2, 3] == Just 3
```

`view` might surprise you. It assumes that the wrapped values
are a monoid, and `append`s them together:

```purescript
view traversed ["D", "a", "w", "n"] == "Dawn"
```

Many of the functions you'll use are documented in `Data.Lens.Fold`.

declarations.comments:
A `Traversal` for the elements of a `Traversable` functor.

```purescript
over traversed negate [1, 2, 3] == [-1,-2,-3]
over traversed negate (Just 3) == Just -3
```
declarations.title: traversed

declarations.comments:
Combine an index and a traversal to narrow the focus to a single
element. Compare to `Data.Lens.Index`. 

```purescript
set     (element 2 traversed) 8888 [0, 0, 3] == [0, 0, 8888]
preview (element 2 traversed)      [0, 0, 3] == Just 3
```
The resulting traversal is called an *affine traversal*, which
means that the traversal focuses on one or zero (if the index is out of range)
results.
declarations.title: element

declarations.comments: Turn a pure profunctor `Traversal` into a `lens`-like `Traversal`.
declarations.title: traverseOf

declarations.comments:
Sequence the foci of an optic, pulling out an "effect".
If you do not need the result, see `sequenceOf_` for `Fold`s.

`sequenceOf traversed` has the same result as `Data.Traversable.sequence`:

```purescript
sequenceOf traversed (Just [1, 2]) == [Just 1, Just 2]
sequence             (Just [1, 2]) == [Just 1, Just 2]
```

An example with effects:
```purescript
> array = [random, random]
> :t array
Array (Eff ... Number)

> effect = sequenceOf traversed array
> :t effect
Eff ... (Array Number)

> effect >>= logShow
[0.15556037108154985,0.28500369615270515]
unit
```
declarations.title: sequenceOf

declarations.comments:
Tries to map over a `Traversal`; returns `empty` if the traversal did
not have any new focus.
declarations.title: failover

declarations.comments: Traverse elements of an `IndexedTraversal` whose index satisfy a predicate.
declarations.title: elementsOf

declarations.comments: Turn a pure profunctor `IndexedTraversal` into a `lens`-like `IndexedTraversal`.
declarations.title: itraverseOf

declarations.comments: The `Exchange` profunctor characterizes an `Iso`.
declarations.title: Exchange

declarations.comments: The `Market` profunctor characterizes a `Prism`.
declarations.title: Market

declarations.comments: The `Shop` profunctor characterizes a `Lens`.
declarations.title: Shop

declarations.comments: The `Stall` profunctor characterizes an `AffineTraversal`.
declarations.title: Stall

declarations.comments: Class for profunctors that support polymorphic traversals.
declarations.title: Wander

modules.name: Data.Lens.Types
modules.comments: This module defines types for working with lenses.

declarations.comments: An affine traversal (has at most one focus, but is not a prism).

declarations.comments: A generalized isomorphism.
declarations.title: Iso

declarations.comments:
Given a type whose "focus element" always exists,
a lens provides a convenient way to view, set, and transform
that element.

For example, `_2` is a tuple-specific `Lens` available from `Data.Lens`, so:
```purescript
over _2 String.length $ Tuple "ignore" "four" == Tuple "ignore" 4
```
Note the result has a different type than the original tuple.
That is, the four `Lens` type variables have been narrowed to:

* `s` is `Tuple String String`
* `t` is `Tuple String Int`
* `a` is `String`
* `b` is `Int`

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens

declarations.comments:
`Lens'` is a specialization of `Lens`. An optic of type `Lens'`
can change only the value of its focus,
not its type. As an example, consider the `Lens` `_2`, which has this type:

```purescript
_2 :: forall s t a b. Lens (Tuple s a) (Tuple t b) a b
```

`_2` can produce a `Tuple Int String` from a `Tuple Int Int`:

```purescript
set _2 "NEW" (Tuple 1 2) == (Tuple 1 "NEW")
```

If we specialize `_2`'s type with `Lens'`, the following will not
type check:

```purescript
set (_2 :: Lens' (Tuple Int Int) Int) "NEW" (Tuple 1 2)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens'

declarations.comments: A prism.
declarations.title: Prism

declarations.comments: A setter.
declarations.title: Setter

declarations.comments: A traversal.
declarations.title: Traversal

declarations.comments: A traversal.
declarations.title: Traversal

declarations.comments:
`Lens'` is a specialization of `Lens`. An optic of type `Lens'`
can change only the value of its focus,
not its type. As an example, consider the `Lens` `_2`, which has this type:

```purescript
_2 :: forall s t a b. Lens (Tuple s a) (Tuple t b) a b
```

`_2` can produce a `Tuple Int String` from a `Tuple Int Int`:

```purescript
set _2 "NEW" (Tuple 1 2) == (Tuple 1 "NEW")
```

If we specialize `_2`'s type with `Lens'`, the following will not
type check:

```purescript
set (_2 :: Lens' (Tuple Int Int) Int) "NEW" (Tuple 1 2)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
declarations.title: Lens'

declarations.comments:
Given a type whose "focus element" always exists,
a lens provides a convenient way to view, set, and transform
that element.

For example, `_2` is a tuple-specific `Lens` available from `Data.Lens`, so:
```purescript
over _2 String.length $ Tuple "ignore" "four" == Tuple "ignore" 4
```

Note the result has a different type than the original tuple.
That is, the four `Lens` type variables have been narrowed to:

* `s` is `Tuple String String`
* `t` is `Tuple String Int`
* `a` is `String`
* `b` is `Int`

See `Data.Lens.Getter` and `Data.Lens.Setter` for functions and operators
frequently used with lenses.
